newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Move to extend Ramos term dealt another blow.
newsitem.headline: Move to extend Ramos term dealt another blow.

text.p: Attempts by a citizens group to change the Philippine constitution and give President Fidel Ramos the chance to run for a second term in office received a near-death blow on Tuesday.
The seven-member Commission on Elections (Comelec) voted unanimously to throw out a petition by the group, called Pirma, that called for a referendum to amend the 10-year-old constitution.

Political analysts said the ruling did not totally close the door on a re-election bid by Ramos despite his public pledge to step down when his term ends next year. Under the law, Ramos can convene Congress into a special assembly to rewrite the constitution, which limits a president to one term of six years. The ban is intended to prevent a repetition of late Ferdinand Marcos' ruinous 20-year rule.

The Comelec decision was the second defeat suffered by Pirma in its campaign to scrap the limit and allow Ramos to run for re-election in the June 1998 polls. Earlier, the Supreme Court also rejected the petition.
Comelec said the Supreme Court had already spoken and "it is our duty to abide by it."

Pirma collected more than five million signatures on its petition. Among those who signed were six members of Ramos' cabinet, which fuelled speculation that he was interested in a second term if he could find a legal way to do it.
